alert.note: Alert for Larimer (Colorado) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued June 04 at 11:10AM MDT by NWS Boulder
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1230 PM MDT THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...A large portion of the Cameron Peak burn scar in Larimer county. * WHEN...Until 1230 PM MDT. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. River or stream flows are elevated. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1105 AM MDT, Doppler radar indicated numerous rain showers will continue through at least mid afternoon. Rainfall rates have generally been around 1 to 2 tenths per hour with a few local amounts up to a third of an inch per hour. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are expected over the area through today. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Kinikinik, Stove Prairie, Pennock Pass, Pingree Park, Rustic, Mishawaka, Glen Haven, Buckhorn Mountain, Red Feather Lakes, Masonville and Horsetooth Mountain. - This includes the following additional locations... Box Prairie, Upper Buckhorn along County Road 44H, Moondance Way, Stringtown Gulch, Big Bear, Lower Buckhorn on County Road 27 above Masonville, Crystal Mountain, Poudre Springs, Monument Gulch, Jacks Gulch, Upper Pingree Park Road, Lower Pingree Park Road, Sky Ranch, Gulches along Highway 14 near and above Rustic, Rising water and large debris in the Poudre River, Pingree Hill, Goodell Corner, Bellaire Lake, Crown Point Road, The Retreat, Storm Mountain and Remote areas in the Comanche Peak Wilderness.
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Heavy Rainfall will cause minor flooding of creeks and streams, roads and roadside culverts in the affected part of the Cameron Peak burn area. The heavy rains could also trigger rock slides or debris flows.
